message.content:
We first explain how each ratio is computed.

1. Accounts Receivable Turnover Ratio

• Formula: 
  Total Revenue / Average Accounts Receivable
• Since on 2023‑12‑31 the Accounts Receivable was 0 and on 2024‑02‑05 it is 10,537,836.59, the average is:
  (0 + 10,537,836.59) / 2 = 5,268,918.295
• Total Revenue (from income statement) is 18,062,437.45.
• Thus, the ratio = 18,062,437.45 / 5,268,918.295 ≈ 3.43

2. Operating Cash Flow Ratio 
  and Operating Cash Flow to Current Liabilities Ratio

• In our data, the “Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities” is –13,358,400.82 and “Total Current Liabilities” is 1,903,121.89.
• The ratio = Operating Cash Flow / Current Liabilities = –13,358,400.82 / 1,903,121.89 ≈ –7.02
• (In the example both ratios are identical.)

3. Total Asset Turnover Ratio

• Formula: 
  Total Revenue / Average Total Assets
• Here, beginning Total Assets was 28,000,000.00 and ending Total Assets is 31,154,033.87.
• Average Total Assets = (28,000,000.00 + 31,154,033.87) / 2 = 29,577,016.935
• Thus, the ratio = 18,062,437.45 / 29,577,016.935 ≈ 0.61

4. Debt to Equity Ratio

• Formula:
  Total Liabilities / Total Owner’s Equity
• The liabilities (in this problem the only items under liabilities are the current liabilities) total 1,903,121.89, and the ending Owner’s Equity is 29,250,911.98.
• Therefore, Debt to Equity Ratio = 1,903,121.89 / 29,250,911.98 ≈ 0.0651, which rounds to about 0.07.

Thus, we present the final results in the required format.

{
  "solution": {
    "Accounts Receivable Turnover Ratio": "3.43",
    "operating cash flow ratio": "-7.02",
    "operating cash flow to current liabilities ratio": "-7.02",
    "Total Asset Turnover Ratio": "0.61",
    "Debt to Equity Ratio": "0.07"
  }
}
